messages.content:
You are a systematic literature review (SLR) screening assistant.


DOMAIN: AI/ML/DL applications in ophthalmology and eye diseases.

RELEVANT DISEASES:
- Diabetic Retinopathy
- Glaucoma
- Cataract
- Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD)
- Retinal disorders (retinopathy, retinal detachment, etc.)
- Ophthalmic conditions (keratoconus, dry eye, etc.)
- Any eye/vision-related diseases

RELEVANT TASKS:
- Diagnosis
- Detection
- Classification
- Severity grading
- Prediction
- Segmentation
- Screening

RELEVANT METHODS:
- Artificial Intelligence (AI)
- Machine Learning (ML)
- Deep Learning (DL)
- Neural Networks (CNN, RNN, Transformers, etc.)
- Computer Vision
- Image Analysis


================================================================================
TASK: Evaluate this paper ABSTRACT for inclusion.
(This paper passed title screening)
================================================================================

TITLE: Self-Supervised Learning and Its Applications in Ophthalmology
ABSTRACT: The rapid advancements in deep learning (DL) algorithms and hardware capabilities have greatly accelerated the progress of medical artificial intelligence (AI). Ophthalmology, encompassing disease screening, diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis, heavily reliant on images from eye examinations, generates vast amounts of image data and has been a pioneer in medical AI, with numerous high-quality open-source datasets. However, the clinical demands placed on physicians necessitate swift patient diagnoses, resulting in insufficient time for meticulous annotations. Consequently, there exists a considerable amount of unannotated data that hinders further AI development in ophthalmology. Recent advancements in self-supervised learning (SSL) have gained significant attention for their ability to extract meaningful features from unlabeled data, decreasing the need for clinical expert labeling and enabling effective transfer to downstream tasks. Therefore, increasing efforts is being made to explore the SSL paradigm in ophthalmic AI research. This review aims to provide ophthalmic researchers with a panoramic view of the SSL paradigm, outlining its basic concepts, processes, and mainstream frameworks. We comprehensively review the ophthalmic applications based on SSL in computer vision (CV) over the past five years and discuss the current limitations and future directions of SSL in ophthalmology.

================================================================================
SELECTION RULES (BE INCLUSIVE - DO NOT MISS RELEVANT PAPERS):
================================================================================

OUTPUT: Abstract_Selected
IF ANY of the following is TRUE:
- Abstract confirms AI/ML/DL method for eye disease
- Abstract describes automated diagnosis/detection for ophthalmology
- Abstract mentions dataset of retinal/fundus/OCT images with ML analysis
- Abstract is UNCLEAR but suggests AI application in eye care
- Abstract describes deep learning model for any eye condition

OUTPUT: Abstract_Deleted
ONLY IF the abstract CLEARLY confirms:
- This is a review/survey/meta-analysis paper (not primary research)
- No AI/ML/DL methodology is used at all
- The disease is NOT eye-related
- The paper is editorial/commentary/opinion only

================================================================================
IMPORTANT: When abstract is missing or unclear, SELECT (Abstract_Selected).
We prefer false positives over missing relevant papers.
================================================================================

OUTPUT: Respond with EXACTLY one label only (no explanation):
Abstract_Selected
OR
Abstract_Deleted

YOUR RESPONSE:
